utterances: Yay!
And also YouTube.
Right, and the Mosh Pit, yeah, I think unfortunately they do follow SNL, and they think this is where it's all originating from.

But my sources, like I said, in Washington, D.C., tell me that one of the reasons why see the media picking sides and taking sides is not because SNL ran this skit and is weighing in on this election.
It's because these media organizations really are hurting and are short on change to cover this race.
And Robert, can you confirm we did not ask you for that endorsement of our services?
That's right.
All right.
On that note, thanks, guys.
Thank you.
Thank you, Farai.
We've been talking with Robert Redding, who publishes The ReddingNewsReview.com.
He was on the line from Radio People Studios in Monroe, Louisiana.
Also Kym Platt, who blogs at AskThisBlackWoman.com, and writer Harry Allen, who blogs at HarryAllen.info.
They both joined me from our NPR studios in New York.
But first, let's go back to presidential politics.
There's been a lot of attention paid to each and every word uttered by the candidates, but what about the people behind those words, the advisors who are shaping their platforms.
Here at Day to Day, we are taking a look at these behind the scenes players.
According to the polls, the top concern of many voters right now is the economy.
And so this week, we're looking at each campaign's economics advisers.
Today, we meet Austan Goolsbee.
He's a University of Chicago economist who has become Illinois Senator Barack Obama's go-to guy when it comes to financial policy.
Chicago Public Radio's Ben Calhoun reports.
How old are you?
I also think it means that Romney's going to hold on to his delegates.
Huckabee will work harder in some of the campaigns.
They might be - wanted to extract something from the presumptive candidate and hold those delegates as hostage.
One of the issues is going to be how they can move toward the convention without further fracturing the Republican base.
Here's McCain, speaking to the conservatives just a couple of hours after Romney.
Senator JOHN McCAIN (Republican, Arizona; Presidential Candidate): Many of you have disagreed strongly with some positions I have taken in recent years.
I understand that.
I might not agree with it, but I respect it for the principled position it is.

And it is my sincere hope that even if you believe I have occasionally erred in my reasoning as a fellow conservative, you will still allow that I have, in many ways important to all of us, maintained the record of a conservative.
What would it take, Ron, for McCain to bridge that gap with the conservatives?
Would it take a Hillary Clinton nomination, for example?
Well, that's certainly a possibility because, you know, she, at least for the right-wing conservatives, could mobilize their base.
But I just don't think that he has the time or the inclination, really, to bridge the gap in issue terms.
I think that at some point before the convention, the inevitable will set it.
And as you can begin to see - as Michael is right - many of the conservative heads of organizations are beginning now to tack(ph) toward him.
And I would expect that that process will continue because they won't have a choice.
I suppose that is the next question, whether or not the Republican nominee - be it McCain or Huckabee or whomever - can they win?
Can that party win, Michael, without the support of the right wing of the party?
No, they cannot win without their base energized, active and voting enthusiastically in November.
They - the last few elections have been very much based on turnout.
And if they can't mobilize their key base, they're in real trouble.
Well, when do they sit down to try to work this out?
And the other question is at what point do you need to have your nominee in place so that you can begin focusing your efforts, not on each other but on the other party's candidate?
I guess what's…
Well, I think they would really…
Oh, go ahead.
I was just going to say they would really like to get this settled as soon possible.
But I believe Ron is about to say, at least by the convention, they really…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…should be - they have to have it settled.
Well, Ron, to you, final thing about the Republicans and then we'll start talking about the Democrats.
The Republicans are holding a caucus tomorrow in Kansas, a primary in Louisiana.
How significant are either of those?
I think very significant because it might begin to build the base for a post-Super Tuesday momentum for Barack Obama.
He looks good in both places.
The governor of Kansas has come out for him; a strong black population in Louisiana.
And so it looks as though the expectations are that he will begin to win those.

Well, that was partly my question, because I was going to get into the Democrats more specifically because they're holding caucuses in Nebraska and Washington state, and a primary in Louisiana on Saturday, which you've already made some reference to.
But let me come to you, Michael, in terms of the significance of the weekend for both Obama and Clinton to do well in those contests, especially with regard to picking up delegates.
Well, you left the key.

I think what Obama really needs is to start - he needs a good rush into March 4th, because March 4th is where the Clinton campaign thinks they have their firewall, so to speak, they have what - they're looking toward, again, big states like Ohio and Texas, to put them back on the map.
But he needs to be very strong on the 9th.
He needs to be strong on the 12th and on the 19th.

If he can pick up some more of the caucuses, if he can sweep the Potomac Primaries, then he'll have built up the momentum, raised the money that might going to push him through in some of the big states that he has some problems with.
Along that same line, Ron, since Super Tuesday alone, both Democratic contenders are saying that they have raised enormous amounts of money mostly through online support.
Now, the Clinton camp reports raising about $7.5 million in the last week, $6.5 million of that in the last day and a half, but she also had to lend her campaign $5 million from her own purse.
Now, on the other side, Barack Obama reported just over $7 million raised since last Tuesday, none of it from his own pocket.
How important is the cost of a prolonged campaign for either or both of them?
Well, it's extremely important because I think that what happened was that the Clinton administration - I mean, the Clinton campaign sort of bet the farm on Super Tuesday.
Going into January, they were about at 18,500 apiece, and they were geared, actually, to spend most of that money in these states in order to come out with a stronger delegate count.
The Obama people raised an enormous amount of money in January, $32 million, million dollars a day, and that gave them the capacity, not only to compete Super Tuesday, but also afterward.
And so, I think that she's got to win.
She's got - Michael is right, coming into March 4th, as the firewall, the scuttlebut is that if she doesn't do well on March 4th, there will be the drumbeat for her to get out.
So she's got to spend that money that she's not raising very wisely, wisely enough to win some very important races on March 4th.
Let me follow that point up with you - with this.
The superdelegates are already an issue, as we've said, because if there is a brokered convention, their votes could be key to who gets the nomination.

In fact, White House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has defended the superdelegate system, but at the same time, one of those 800 or so superdelegates, strategist Donna Brazile, has said - and this is a quote - ""If 795 of my colleagues decide this election, I will quit the Democratic Party.
I feel very strongly about this,"" end quote.
This is a big issue, isn't it?
It's a big issue, and it really came up during the Jackson administration.
I testified before the Rules Committee to have a one person, one vote.
They put in the 15 percent threshold to get delegates, and they created the superdelegates.
What they wanted to do is to go back to the smoke-filled room, because the party leaders, the party bosses felt that they didn't have a role in selecting the nominee anymore.
So what Donna is saying, in effect, that if the smoke-filled room is created, and particularly if it goes against Barack Obama - he may be in second place then - it will mean it would look very bad.

And this is very important because you could alienate the base of the Democratic Party going into the fall election and cost them tremendous stakes like the expansion of the party in the Senate and the House and maybe even the White House.
This is my last question.
We have less than a minute.
It's coming to you, Michael.
I need you to give me as concise an answer as you can.
What about voter fatigue?
After months of political contests and media attention, will it be harder to get voters out to the polls in places like Pennsylvania in April and Indiana in May?
If the race is still close, people will come out.
People are still energized.
People are still extraordinarily interested in a very unique campaign.
So you think that that won't have much of an impact one way or the other?
Unless the race is already decided, I don't think it will have much of an impact at all.
You share that view, Ron Walters?
Yes, I do.
All right.
Michael, Ron, I want to appreciate - I want to thank both of you for coming on with us.
We appreciate it.
Ron Walters is a professor of political science at the University of Maryland.
He spoke with us from our NPR headquarters in Washington, D.C.
Michael Dawson is a professor of political science at the University of Chicago.
He spoke with us from the studios at the University of Chicago.
St.
Louis recently increased its minimum wage to $10 an hour, more than $2 higher than the rest of the state.
But the Missouri legislature has just passed a bill to nullify that city law, which means some St. Louis workers will likely lose raises they just got.
St. Louis Public Radio's Jason Rosenbaum has more.
